I was sooo pleasantly surprised that it was actually packed with the sweet ube flavor that was vital to my childhood.

I especially liked that most of the workers were family. Those behind the counter seemed to be in their teens or young adults and they were working so earnestly despite the difficulty of keeping up with the crowd. Kudos to them for still being so friendly and serving us so quickly! 

I realllllly want to give this place a 5 but I don't feel like the size of the scoops merit its price point. But don't let this deter you from getting something tasty from here. 

If you're in the area, please give this place a shot.
author: Nikki F.

description:
New ice cream shop in the Mission that does not disappoint with its commitment to Asian flavors. Now if you've already tried Humphrey, Birite and Mitchel's, it's probably time for you to check out Garden. 

Luckily, it's open on the later side, it's pretty centrally located in the Mission (compared to the others which are more on the corners of the district), and everyone who works here is super friendly. Since nobody knows this place exists yet, there is no crazy line when you visit. 

I got the mango sticky rice and coconut pudding combination as a single scoop, bless. Since I was a fatty who tried a bunch of flavors, there were definitely a ton of stand outs (milk tea, matcha, thai tea, etc.) that will make the decision to choose two flavors pretty difficult. SO maybe you should opt for two scoops and get three flavors. 

Come to GC and get a fill on these flavors that you can't find in other creameries in the city.
author: Arezou A.

description: It's never bad to have ice cream options, and having Garden Creamery only makes life harder to choose! I was wandering around the Mission and happened to walk by Garden Creamery by pure chance. Thankfully, it was right when they opened so waiting wasn't a big deal! I was probably their first customer of the day! I really had the HARDEST time choosing what to get. I was debating between all of the fantastic Asian-inspired flavors and had to go with half scoop of the Matcha Gold and a half scoop of the Japanese Milk Tea. Yep, you can get two mini scoops in one cup! Makes indecision making much easier! I loved both and really loved how original the flavors were. I will definitely be back!!
author: Lisa I.

description:
The cone. THE CONE! The crispy, still-warm latticed waffle cone. You have to get this. I've never tasted a homemade cone as good as this, and yet it's not being talked about on Yelp. 

In the ice cream dept., choosing a flavor is tough. You see, every flavor is a win here.

My favorites: the Haupia Macadamia (an incredible dose of Hawaii) and the Thai Iced Tea sorbet (icy, yet creamy and so refreshing).

Runner-ups were the Mango Sticky Rice ice cream and the Banana Salted Caramel. 

5 stars!!!!!!
author: Bonnie G.

description:
My new favorite ice cream spot in the mission. Perfect for a hot afternoon. 

I got two scoops. 1) Pandan Coconut and 2) Japanese Milk Coffee. Both are a must try. 

I love Pandan, so it was extremely satisfying to see that they had it in ice cream form. And to my pleasure, it did not disappoint! That uniquely sweet and elegant Pandan flavor stood out strongly and I was very happy.

The Japanese milk coffee was exceptional as well, but if you're looking for only one flavor then go with the Pandan. The milk coffee tasted similar to Haagen Dazs' coffee flavor (nothing wrong with that btw cause I love it), but felt lighter and smoother. 

If you love ice cream, you MUST check this place out.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
I love that Garden Creamery has actual asian flavors. Genmaicha, Hojicha, Pandan, Ube, Kinako, thai tea, black sesame, of course Matcha, and many other classic flavors too like cookies 'n cream. Their 'Single scoop' is two generous scoops if you decide to get two flavours, and for a double scoop you can get two to three flavours. The servers are super nice and let you sample lots of flavours! I tried a lot of the flavours and I really liked the hawaiian butter mochi flavor. They rotate flavors too so I'm excited to come back and try some of their other flavours.

They have a churro cone for a limited time on Saturdays, and I'm sure it's quite good (I haven't tried it yet). I love that they have dairy free 'sorbets' even with flavours that aren't traditionally considered sorbet flavours, like earl grey, thai tea, etc. 

Plus, the line is super reasonable which is ALWAYS a plus in my book especially in SF - also, Smitten is right around the corner so if the line's too long here, you can always try to go to Smitten. (but maybe it'll get more and more crowded once more people hear about this place...)
author: Theresa L.

description:
I actually prefer this place over some of the other more popular ice cream shops in SF.  they have a lot of unique tea flavors that you won't find anywhere else.  

my current FTOM is Mac nut.  been here a couple times now and there's usually a consistent line, but nothing that's been too crazy.  it's usually because ppl want to try all their flavors.

pretty  basic on the inside of the shop with a couple of tables and a small set of bar tables to enjoy your dessert.  one of these days, I'll have to come for their chimney cone as it's a limited cone on Saturdays from 2-4.

although it costs more than other shops, it's well deserving as it might keep some people away and lines shorter for me.
author: Roger K.

description:
4.8.17

FLAVORS ARE SPOT ON. Organic and fresh! I am the biggest fan of tea inspired flavors and this place is literally ICE CREAM HEAVEN! They have various unique flavors of ice cream including non-dairy ice cream for you vegans and lactose intolerant ice cream lovers :) Parking is unsurprisingly hard to find considering it's located in the mission district, but we got super lucky and grabbed street parking right across this joint. 

ICE CREAM: 
2 full scoops of ice cream is their "Single" price at $4.50 including a cone or cup OR both if you want to avoid the mess and keep the cone. THIS PRICE IS AMAZING, compared to many similar ice cream parlors. I promise, you'll stand in front of the ice cream bar and want to sample every flavor. Their flavors seem to be Hawaiian/Asian oriented including: 
+ uji mathca 
+ hojicha (roasted green tea) 
+ hawaiian butter mochi w/ sesame 
+ mango sticky rice 
+ roasted soy 
+ coconut pandan 
+ banana papaya 
+ MUCH MORE

(non-dairy) 
+ earl grey 
+ strawberry guava habanero 
+ thai tea 
+ banana lilikoi (passion fruit)
+ Kona coffee  
+ MUCH MORE  

Other than ice cream they have sundaes, pops, ice cream cookie sandwiches. Unfortunately we missed the time for the chimney cone (offered 2-4pm on Sat). You can also ask for pint sized to go. 

AMBIANCE: 
Decently sized with single window seats and some group seating along the back that can seat up to about 4-6. With the large windows I would imagine that it would be very bright during the day. 

SERVICE: 
Very friendly staff who do not rush you while choosing your flavors. They even offer suggestions for flavor pairings. yes! 

Verdict: would definitely be back to test out their other flavors and possibly new flavors.
author: Samantha F.

description: If you're in the mission and go to any ice cream shop but Garden Creamery you're robbing yourself. The Madagascar Vanilla Brownie is to die for and the Cookies & Cream is better than any I've ever had. They also have a variety of non-dairy/vegan options.  Pro-tip: If it's a Saturday between 2-4pm grab their signature chimney cone. You won't regret it.
author: Anthony M.

description: Very light.  Very natural.  Very special flavors  only a short wait  this is one of my favor ice cream shop in the city
author: Ed Y.

description:
The chimney cone (made from churros!!!) is amazing. It was hard to choose which flavor to pair with the cone, but they let you try as many as you like. In the end I went with Thai Tea, which was the perfect embodiment of the drink in ice cream form.

Important to note: This special cone is only available 2-4 on Saturdays, so expect a line.

The inside of this place is amazing too. Amazing, amazing ice cream. Totally worth the wait.
author: Ariana R.

description:
Garden Creamery is San Francisco's hottest new ice cream shop! Recently transitioning from a mobile ice cream truck to a brick-and-mortar, their delicious creamy treats are now more visible and accessible for everyone to enjoy. I have to admit that I was initially skeptical their ice cream could compete with the likes of Bi-Rite and Mitchell's, but that completely went out the window after my first visit. 

The shop is welcoming and bright with clean white tables topped with tiny potted succulents,  cucumber-infused water, and a glass case filled with 24 heavenly flavors. About half the case is devoted to coconut milk or water based vegan sorbets, which is great for those who are lactose intolerant or have nut allergies. Their regular ice cream is made with organic milk from Straus Family Creamery. Churro Chimney Cones are currently available on Saturdays from 2-4pm (I hope they expand those hours!). 

The intensity, accuracy, and uniqueness of their flavors took me by surprise. Mango Pico de Gallo, Thai Tea, Coconut Lemongrass, Banana Lilikoi Passion...and Genmaicha?! Only my favorite tea EVER. Genmaicha is a toasted brown rice green tea and is rather subtle in flavor, but they captured it perfectly! 

I settled on Matcha Toffee, Black Sesame, and Genmaicha and they were all creamy, dense, and flavorful - not to mention a great combination and completely Instagrammable! I couldn't stop "mmm'ing" after each spoonful. They're really something special.

In a city with fierce competition and high rent, your product has to be top notch, and Garden Creamery's got it. I love Bi-Rite, but their ice cream isn't nearly as creamy or densely flavorful. GC's prices are slightly above average, but on par with shops with similar concept and quality, starting at $4.25 a scoop. Totally worth it. I can't wait to go back!
author: Deanna Y.

description:
This is the best asian fusion ice cream shop in San Francisco.  Every time that I have guests in town or have a craving for ice cream, Garden Creamery is my go-to spot.  

I recommend the ube or the black sesame ice cream as staples.  Each month the flavors are rotated and are seasonal as well.  

11/10 would recommend
author: Craig V.

description: Absolutely amazing ice cream. With all the surrounding ice cream spots, this one is underrated. I wish there was more sitting space but the ice cream alone is worth it and if you can find a seat, more power to you. The staff is also friendly and they take their time with each customer, no matter how long the line. If you love ice cream as much as I do, it doesn't get more quality and satisfying than this
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
This is a popular and fairly new ice cream and vegan sorbet spot so I had to give them a try. They're undeniably popular, a line formed out the door and onto the side street. It was a good 25 minutes as we anxiously waited to order our ice cream. Half of the flavors are made with coconut milk, so it's a great option for people who are lactose and cannot have the delight that is ice cream. The other half is made with organic Straus milk, you can find the menu breakdown on their website. 

There is a variety of different and unique flavors to choose from. I got a single scoop (1-2 flavors) and picked Hojicha and Earl Grey. The Earl Grey flavor was absolutely delicious, I love Earl Grey ever since I tried it with boba. This flavor is vegan, but it tasted no different from regular dairy. The Hojicha was an interesting flavor and one that I would get again. The texture and consistency of their ice cream was great and the sweetness level was good.

Feel free to ask for samples until you are ready to choose. Despite it being busy, the workers didn't rush us and were happy to provide us with more samples to try. Only a few tables in the small place, so if they're occupied, eat while walking to the next destination!
author: Vincent P.

description:
I feel so conflicted about the growing popularity of Garden Creamery and about adding another 5 star review to their yelp page. On the one hand, yes, I think they're amazing and probably my new favorite ice cream place in SF and they totally deserve the praise. But on the other hand, I don't want anyone to know about it because I hate long lines. I love all their different japanese and hawaiian inspired flavors, and what stands out to me the most if the fact that they have SO many different varieties of matcha flavors (matcha, hojicha, genmaicha etc etc). 

After many weeks of not having time, I finally got to try out their churro cones this weekend as well (theyre only served from 2-4pm on Saturdays). I was bummed out to hear that you can only have one flavor in the cone, especially since it's a whopping $8. While the churro cone was tasty and definitely instagram-worthy, my bf and I finished it craving more ice cream. Honestly if the line hadn't gotten so insanely long after 2pm I would've bought myself another single scoop! I'd recommend trying the churro cone out once for the picture and since it's pretty unique, but the ice cream is definitely the star of the show!
author: Stephany L.

description:
Yep, new favorite ice cream place. More so than Bi Rite. All these flavors. Lilokai Passion Fruit, Hojicha Tea, and Black Sesame. 

I'm coming back to check the Guabanero and Chimney cone.

SOOOO GOOOD!!! Secret that's not to secret: this place makes me so happy. Anyone who's reading this and thinks I deserve a gift card or gift of some sort, Garden Creamery is the way to go :D
author: Annie L.

description:
New ice cream shop in the city that brings new flavors to those of us who have had our fill of birite, Humphrey, Mitchell's, and mr/mrs miscellaneous. Open late, even on a Sunday. Parking, well....it's the mission so go figure. 

Now onto the flavors. Not sure about flavor rotations, but from what I saw today they definitely bring new variety to the city. Fortunately for my waistline, I did not get to sample them all, yet. I did sample two of the tea flavors and the genmaicha was on point. The lilikoi coconut can be skipped, I found that it was neither lilikoi-y nor coconut-y for my liking. The black sesame was good but other shops have it also. 

The one flavor that stuck out was definitely the Hawaiian butter mochi. For those of you who have had an actual Hawaiian butter mochi (you know, the ones from that roadside stand in Hanalei Kauai) then you will know what I mean when I say the flavor is like a heavenly explosion on your tongue. Not sure how they managed to capture the flavor of the butter mochi into ice cream, but I'm sure glad they did. If they managed to actually make a butter mochi and serve it with the ice cream, I think I'd be here everyday.
author: Long C.

description: I was disappointed to see this place only has their churro chimney cones on Saturdays from 2-4PM and really you would have no idea about these specifics unless you were in store to see it on their menu. Aside from this, the ice cream flavors were pretty interesting as they were very Asian influenced including flavors like matcha, and Thai ice tea. The ice cream itself is good, the consistency is perfectly creamy and not too melty. My favorite flavor from here is definitely the haupia (coconut.) Don't think I'd come here if it were out of my way, but I would come back if it were convenient.
author: Jacqueline T.

description:
Yum? Soo good! Came here on the weekend with the bro. Kinda hidden to find and hope you don't miss it as you drive by. It's the red building. They have a lot of different flavor options that is not your typically baskin robin sugar flavors. I like that they had a lot of Asian inspire flavors. Especially since they had halo halo flavor whaaat?!?!?!? 

It's a smaller shop with seating. Doesn't feel overly crowded either even if it's busy. The severs are all nice and friendly and fast which is always a plus. Typical pricing for ice cream shops. Definitely will come back again and again.
author: Denice D.

description: They had unique flavors (matcha w/toffee, black sesame, etc) but to be honest they just didn't taste that great to me. Don't get me wrong- I finished my cup of ice cream and I enjoyed trying out unique flavors but I just didn't think the ice cream tasted that great. In addition, I'm docking a star because my boyfriend got a double but in the cup it basically looked the same serving size as the single I got even though it cost 50% more (we both ended up with 2 scoops in a cup, just in different size cups).
author: Hyan P.

description:
TIPS:
-CHIMNEY CONES (those sugary churro looking things) are only offered from 2-4 on SATURDAYS
-The chimney cones are only allowed 1 (possibly two scoops depending on who's working)
-street parking
-even if it's not Saturday, go anyways because the ice cream alone is good

So my friends and I went to garden creamery after hearing all good things about it and seeing it all over my feed. We went in planning to get like 4 scoops each because we had seen others do it and because we love ice cream too much. The people working said they weren't allowed to and could only give us two (after we got our ice cream another employee, possibly manager, told us they should only give 1 scoop because the cone doesn't support well). We went with thai tea, black sesame, matcha, and hojicha. Everything tried was so good though, so choosing just two each was hard enough! The texture is creamy and that chimney cone didn't get too soggy throughout eating. It maintained that yummy crispy exterior while staying nice, soft, and flakey inside. Even if they didn't have these cones, I would still come back just for their ice cream!
author: Maleah M.

description:
UNDOUBTEDLY my favorite ice cream place in San Francisco. Staff is over-the-top friendly, and I really dig the Hawaiian-inspired flavors -- these are the flavors you have to choose from (screw the classics). Trust me. 

THIS is the place I will bring all my friends to whether they are SF locals or visitors. The shop is located on an assuming corner off of Mission St., yet perfectly tucked away from the chaos. My idea of a perfect food date in the Mission would start at El Techo for dinner/ happy hour, followed by the 10-min-ish walk (trust me, you'll need to walk off those carbs.... to prepare for more carb-loading!) to Garden Creamery. That's what I call a proper food mission ;)
author: Liz C.

description:
I think this may be my new favorite ice cream place (replacing Mr and Mrs Miscellaneous). I'm a tropical fruit kinda gal - not a caramel, chocolate, marshmallow, blech type (even thinking of all that sweet overload makes me feel icky) - so Garden Creamery is like the perfect match. They're open until 10pm (!!!!) and it's on my way home so it's hard to not stop by now that I know what's up. 

[ As an aside, kinda funny because they're on my way home that I saw this place being transformed with bright pink paint from the Mexican Bakery into something new and never thought anything of it. I guess I should have paid more attention! ]

Came by Wed just a hair before 10pm and they were nice enough to let me taste as many flavors as I wanted. Of course I took ages and then more people came in and though I was still tasting and it was now getting past 10pm, they didn't seem to mind. My favorites were the coconuts (coconut macadamia nut, coconut pandan) though the roasted soy bean and sesame were also really good. Today was super hot but I really really really wanted to stop by and try the chimney cone.

*** Hot Tip: request the chimney cone with ice cream in a tray, makes it much easier to alternate eating the ice cream and cone.

The line was short but still around the corner at 3pm today. It took about 15-20min and there's orange ice water which is nice. We went for the strawberry guabanero (guava + habanero) which was a sorbet but oh so perfect on a hot day. The chimney cone was a nice yeasty sugary donut like thing. It was like 2 treats in one! It's so decadent I'm not sure I would get it every time. It's probably actually even nicer with a creamy ice cream on a not-quite-so-hot day. Like a cake a la mode but with chimney cone.

$8 for the chimney cone includes 1 scoop of flavor.
author: Jean K.

description: I've been to garden creamery a few times now and finally got the chance to try their chimney cone! First off, their ice cream flavors are unique, many with Asian influence, and they have great service. They don't mind when I ask to try 3 different flavors at a time, which is nice! The ice cream is super creamy and flavorful. The chimney cone is only available during a certain time period on Saturday's and is about $8. It takes a lot like a morning bun that is in a cone shape - delicious, but honestly difficult to eat and it is overwhelmingly filling. I think I prefer just getting the ice cream on a cone, but I would highly recommend coming here!
author: Jacqueline H.

description:
I love the variety of Asian flavors they offer and how the ice creams aren't overly sweet. My favorites have to be the ube pandan and the Japanese coffee. The ube pandan has a strong ube flavor with a more lighter pandan flavor, but you can definitely tell it's there. The Japanese coffee tastes exactly like you made the canned Japanese coffees into ice cream form and it's sooooo good. All their tea flavors and the black sesame are really good too!

Service-wise, I feel like everytime i've come, the staff is not very welcoming/friendly. The scoops are also on the smaller side as well.

Overall, more on the pricier side but yummy ice cream.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Garden Creamery is a fairly new ice cream shop (2 months old) that opened up in the heart of the Mission. I was drooling over the cinnamon Chimney cones so I decided to check this place out around 8pm. The line was fairly long, and went out the door. I think the line would have gone much faster if they had the flavors listed on the wall. Many folks took a while looking at the range of choices when they were in front of the ice cream.

Sadly, they only serve the Chimney cones between 2-4pm! BOO! The group in front of me discovered that too. 

I had a single scoop (2 flavors) of Black Sesame and Hazelnut in the waffle cone. The black sesame was alright (doesn't compare to the incredible black sesame flavor at Icy's in Berkeley) and the hazelnut, which was really good, but nothing new/amazing about it. The waffle cone was really yummy to me and quite unique. 

I'll have to come back to try the Chimney cone.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Super creamy ice cream! The flavors offered are very unique and all delicious. They have plenty of non-dairy options which are surprisingly really good! 

They are closed on Monday's and Tuesday. I found out the hard way - with a craving for ice cream, I walked over to Garden Creamery on a Tuesday evening and they were closed! Don't fret if this happens to you. There are ~20 ice cream shops in the Mission. Smitten is a block away & bi-rite is a few blocks away.

Be ready to wait in line! It's usually busy.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
GARDEN CREAMERY is on my list for favorite creameries in the bay area. 

Never had their Truck before and honestly came in because I know they were serving the Chimney Cones from 2-4pm on Saturdays. Looks awesome on social media therefore a much needed visit before the lines are around the block. The chimney cone was amazing. As they describe it, "SWEET and CRUNCHY on the outside, with a SOFT DOUGHY texture on the inside" No faults advertisement here. It's serve to you still warm because the staff goes into the back (open window) to bring you the cone. So good! Compliments their ice cream so well. 

Now on to the ICE CREAM!! Love the Hazelnut Crunch. Not too sweet, just perfect. Creamiest overload. FYI their single scoops are huge. Loved every bite. 

I also recommend the Matcha + Toasted Rice, The Nutty Professor and Black Sesame. I can't wait to go back and try taro and ube.
author: Sandy B.

description:
Finally had the chance to check this place out on a Sunday evening (4/9/17). 

It is just as colorful and iconic looking from the street as in all the IG photos. I was so excited to get to try their frozen delights, and boy did they deliver on the quality. There was a short line, but moved quickly. They had three people working the counter, serving samples, and scooping'. Staff was super friendly and happy to let you sample whatever you'd like.

They have a section of non-dairy and traditional ice creams. On this visit, I only tried their dairy ice creams, but from what I tasted I could have been thrilled with anything coming out of that case. Every flavor I tried (Hawaiian Butter Mochi, Genmaicha, Banana Papaya, and Black Sesame) was smooth, creamy, and distinct. I consider myself, and certainly others note that I am, an ice cream aficionado. I am always seeking frozen treats that have that smooth as silk texture, are super creamy,  and have a distinct flavor.  So I mean this when I say, Garden Creamery is the real deal.

Ultimately walked away with Hawaiian Butter Mochi + Black Sesame in a waffle cone. It was nothing short of amazing. Seriously, seriously, seriously you have to try that butter mocha if they have it. It is UNREAL!!

Keep in mind if you're after the much hyped chimney cones these are only served 2-4pm on Saturdays!
author: Megan A.

description:
Why does the Mission District have so much good places to eat?! I mean it's not a bad thing at all but I guess I'll have to start my diet next week again (for the fifth year in a row LOL).

I was drawn in by their "Chimney Cone", which basically is like a cinnamon sugar donut shaped in a cone. Unfortunately, they ran out by the time I got there. SO SAD!!!!!! But the huge variety of ice cream flavors made up for it. IT'S SO WORTH IT!!!!

The employees are very welcoming and patiently helped me choose my 2 flavors for a single scoop. There's so much to choose from! I ended up with the Haupia with Macadamia (Coconut Pudding w/ Macadamia Nuts) & Chocolate Brownie. I....WAS....SPEECHLESS

The flavors were very prominent and I loved the smooth flavor of the coconut milk paired with the roasted nuts. I FELL IN LOVE!!!! And the chocolate brownie was perfectly sweet and rich with flavors of chocolate & brownie pieces swimming through. 

This place is the exact definition of QUALITY. Come pay a visit and you'll see why. In fact, I'll see you there in an hour
author: Ralph N.

description:
Hip ice creamery located in the Mission district of SF? Count me in.
I came here on a warm afternoon on a Saturday, between the hours of 2-4 pm, so Garden Creamery had their special Saturday chimney cones up for grabs.

The flavors are so unique- think: ube pandan, pu-erh tea, mango sticky rice, black sesame, matcha with toffee bits, just to name a few. 

I love that the single scoop allows you 1-2 flavors, and the double gets you 2-3 flavors... it's like a free upgrade so it makes the price tag worth it!

I got a single with ube pandan and mango sticky rice- I loved the ube pandan, and I felt that the mango sticky rice was pretty subtle- I didn't taste the sticky rice flavor too much- it was more of a subtle hint, and there were no sticky rice bits :( 

My bf got a vanilla with brownie in a chimney cone, which is sort of like a huge churro that holds ice cream. Worth the $8? Sort of questionable.

I enjoyed the ice cream flavors and getting to sample flavors prior to choosing, I'm hoping to come back and be able to try more!
author: Mary F.

description:
Very flavorful ice cream.

Unlike humphrey's it doesn't go crazy mixing random ingredients together, rather it takes normal (mostly asian) dessert flavors and turns it into ice cream. Some fun flavors include vegan thai tea, mexican vanilla, coconut pandan, hojicha, and black sesame. The ice cream has a rich texture and holds together well (made from scratch and local ingredients!). You can choose up to 2 flavors for a single scoop and up to 3 for a double scoop. 

In terms of toppings or fancy cones, there aren't too many options, but since I normally get cup scoops, I didn't really pay attention to these details. I did see two fun and colorful ice-cream sandwiches dipped in sprinkles but unsure if those things are customizable like CREAM. They also serve sorbets and pops (will have to come back to check it out!)

What I tried:
-black sesame: a little too sweet for me (ended up losing its flavor to the sweetness) but it's very good black sesame--reminiscent of mochi black sesame soup balls i used to have as a kid
-dairy-free chocolate: extremely chocolate and not too sweet or creamy, very good
-hojicha: a lower sweetness level but the flavor is strong and refreshing
-fresh mint chip: very fresh mint and not that sweet
author: Lydia Z.

description:
I have to say that this is my favorite ice cream place in SF (I like it more than Humphrey's and even bi-rite)! I love the variety of unique flavors here, and the ice cream is creamy without being too overwhelming. 

My first time here, I got the hazelnut in a chimney cone! The hazelnut was just the best decision ever, and there were even ferrero rocher pieces in it!! The chimney cone was a bit too much for me, since I was overloaded with sugar and am not a big sweet tooth! However, it was still delicious! ($8 for a chimney cone, so a bit pricey)

My second time, I got the matcha (forgot the exact name) and black sesame. The matcha tasted fine, but I thought it was weird how they added marshmallow bits in it. The black sesame was delicious and very sesame-y, and tasted toasty. You can get two flavors in one scoop for $4.25, which is a pretty competitive price to all the other ice cream shops!

Meanwhile, I've samples many other flavors such as saffron rose, coconut pandan, coconut pudding (with macadamia nuts), genmaicha, and coffee. These flavors surely did not disappoint, so whatever you get here will definitely knock your socks off!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Who loves going on FB just to read comments on posts?

*RAISES HAND*

Recently, an uneducated idiot with a burnt cheeto as her profile picture commented that San Francisco is not dog-friendly and doesn't have good eateries.

It took more willpower than resisting an In-N-Out Double Double to not reply to her comment. 

San Francisco is extremely dog-friendly and it a culinary mecca with the most restaurants per a capita than any other city in the nation. Just our one block walk from dinner to Garden Creamery, we met at least 8 dogs out and about with their owners.  We even passed by a Great Dane giving high fives for bacon hot dogs: http://bit.ly/2lr3hLD. 

Ice cream truck turned brick and mortar, Garden Creamery has 20 rotating artisan, small-batch ice cream flavors, half of which are vegan (sorbets)! They have unique Asian flavors like Haupia Macadamia Nut, Thai Peanut, Hojicha, Coconut Pandan, Kalo (taro) Cream etc. Try finding that in Utah, burnt cheeto lady! They also have pops and sandwiches on their menu but I didn't see any on the night we went. I've had their Strawberry Pretzel (strawberry mousse dipped in white chocolate and salty pretzels) during their food truck days and it was bomb: http://bit.ly/2l1rvLu. 

Single (1-2 flavors): ice cream - $4.25, sorbert - $4.50; Double (2-3 flavors): ice cream - $6.25, sorbert - $6.50. Pops: $4 and Sandwiches: $5. Sundaes are $7-$7.50. Samples are freely given. Cc's accepted. 

I will be forever a vanilla girl so ordered a Single with Mexican Vanilla and Haupia Macadamia Nut ($4.25): http://bit.ly/2lraGKr. Both were deliciously creamy, smooth, and dense with very little air pockets. If you like coconut and are a texture whore, then you will love the haupia as much I did - coconutty with a delightful buttery crunch from the macadamia. The vanilla was a bit too sweet for me so I would skip that next time. 

I overheard one of the owners telling a customer that Garden Creamery is working on doggie ice cream so I had to inquire more about it. He says that they're working on several flavors including peanut butter bacon and his plan is to have a doggie parking station outside with faux grass. So, you can come inside to grab a scoop for yourself and your furbaby.

How cool is that?!

Garden Creamery, you have earned yourself regular customers! Tater Tot and I will definitely be back!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: The hojicha is to die for here. Just the right amount of sweet and tea flavor. It reminds me of the hoji cha latte in japan.
author: Traci S.

description:
As an ice cream aficionado, this place is a must try!

My first time getting a TRIPLE SCOOP of ice cream without any regrets to my ever expanding waistline. #sorrynotsorry

Mind you, I had also had dessert at The Morris right before I came to Garden Creamery in a time span of less than 10 minutes. 

My triple scoop flavors ($6.50):

- Lilikoi (passion fruit) - one of my favorite tart fruit. It's refreshing and perfect for palette cleansing. 

- Guabanero = guava and habanero to spice things up. I LOVE IT!! This is definitely one of my favorite flavors at Garden Creamery. If you can take the heat, go for it! 

- Earl Grey - sweet and citrusy. One of my favorite stable flavors that I like getting in pearl drinks, so naturally I had to try it as an ice cream flavor. 

Other flavors to try:

- Banana salted caramel = house made caramel with organic bananas. UH-MAZING!!!

- Genmaicha = matcha and toasted rice. I love you so Matcha!

Thank you Garden Creamery for making delicious and unique flavors ice cream. Not to mention, your friendly service and helpful recommendation. 

I hope you give this tasty ice cream place a try. Cheers!

The simple things in life.
author: Owie N.

description:
Ono! The. Best. Ice Cream. Hands down!!
Get outta the way bi-rite, Garden Creamery is here to stay!
The Bi-rite line is crazy (30 mins average), so come over to Garden Creamery instead! Flavors taste like their description and are perfectly balanced with just the right amount of sweetness. You can get li-hing mui sorbet (noms) to vanilla and salted caramel (all noms). I had like 6 samples the first time I came here, and I loved them all. 
LOVE seeing the owner around (go women owners, and go Honolulu family!), and love the staff. They make you feel good for trying their ice cream, not bad. I can't wait to bring my aloha mama here.

If you're here on vacation and only have ONE ice cream place you can visit in the SF Bay Area...choose this one. Locals def approve it.

If you're having a bad day, treat yourself to some Garden Creamery and your frown will turn upside down. :)
author: Sarah W.

description:
Highlights
- If you asked me to pick a Go To ice cream shop that I would take friends visiting SF, this is THE place! I LOVE this ice cream shop and dream about going back every week, but new years resolutions got me holding back. :)
- The intriguing and unique flavors that always rotate are absolutely spot on in nailing the taste of each flavor. Anthing with pandan from here has been A-mazing. Other top flavors in my book include: mango sticky rice, thai tea, almond, candy cane, coconut pandan, ube pandan, earl grey. The ice cream here isn't overly rich, just the perfect amount of refreshing satisfaction for dessert.
- You can't beat the pricing in comparison to the other local hipster ice cream shops. Portion size is great as well. 
- Seating with tables inside the shop with water dispenser for water too

Improvements
- None really, there will be peak times when there is a line after dinner, but it's not that bad and it moves quickly. 
- I like to get ice cream in a cup and put a cone on top, since I don't like my cone with ice cream melting all around dripping nor do I want to be stuck with a flavor at the end that I did not prefer, yes, I'm complicated. Although a sugar cone is free by itself, they charged me $0.25 extra for the cone and cup. No biggie, but something to note.
- I wish the chimney cone was offered during all days of the week, only limited day and time. I always come when it isn't served and am still hoping to try it one of these days. 

Tips
- Parking is difficult in this area although there is residential and street meter nearby
author: Tracy T.

description:
For me, Garden Creamery is the perfect ice cream shop. I don't know if it could get any better. Maybe their waffle cone isn't quite perfect? Open every night of the week?

I love Matcha ice cream, I know I can count on them having it every night. The selection of non-dairy is helpful for when we go with friends who want non-dairy. If you like boring flavors then head to Birite.
author: Dian X.

description:
It was a hot miserable day in SF this past weekend. We were waiting around the area for the chimney cones that are only served 2-4pm on Saturdays. The line was out the door before 2pm! Come early.

The services are friendly and they have pretty unique flavors. Although we did play it safe and got black sesame and mint chip (classics!). The chimney cones are a great treat to the yummy ice cream. They work well together although the cones themselves are hollow. 

There are a few places to sit and there is one bathroom. I'll come again and not just for the chimney cones!
author: Michael T.

description: We waited in line for about 20 minutes to try their ice cream, and it was worth it! We got: ube pandan, matcha gold, and black sesame. All were super delicious! Ube pandan cake out to be our top fave due to the uniqueness of the flavor, and rated high on creaminess. I'm a huge matcha fan, and really enjoyed the matcha gold with full flavored matcha. Sesame was decadent and rich too, but the ube just shined. Will be back to try other flavors. Minus a star for the size of the scoops. Would love it if scoops were a bit more generous.
author: Mei W.

description:
Churro cones. That alone is enough reason to come to check this place out. It's a plus that the ice cream choices are pretty awesome too. 

Came to try this place out because a friend said it was a must try. We stopped by early afternoon and there was a small line outside of the shop already, but nothing too crazy. The line actually moved fairly quickly. 

The ice cream flavors were not your typical Baskin Robbin type flavors. Just to name a few choices from what I could remember:

* Mango sticky rice
* Haupia with macadamia nuts
* Japanese milk coffee
* Banana salted caramel
* Butter mochi
* Coconut pandan
* Earl grey
* Thai tea

I mean c'mon those flavors alone are pretty awesome. 

I tried all the flavors I listed except the last two. I opted for the Banana salted caramel in a "chimney" (churro) cone. It paired amazingly together. The churro cone was fresh and warm. It wasn't heavily doused with cinnamon sugar either. The ice cream tasted like fresh bananas dipped on caramel. Literally spent my time alternating between the ice cream and the cone and taking huge bites of both together. 

Sadly, since I'm not from the area.. I don't get to have this goodness every weekend.. but I would seriously love to come back the next time I'm in town.
author: Melanie N.

description:
I've been to my fair share of hip ice cream places with long lines, and this is one of the only ones that seem worth it to me. Stood in line during one of the HOTTEST days in SF I've ever experienced - it was over 90 degrees. The place is tiny and doesn't have much ventilation - it certainly does not have AC. So while I did sweat my ass off and melt into a puddle while sitting in their stuffy little shop, I had a rather enjoyable time sampling the unique ice cream flavors with my friends. Didn't add any of the toppings, but tried a bunch of flavors. I really enjoyed the Japanese Milk Coffee and Genmaicha (match & toasted rice). Velvety and smooth texture, sweet but not overly sweet. The black sesame was probably the most bizarre ice cream I've ever had, but it was still delicious - toasty yet refreshing at the same time.

I will definitely be coming back here next time I'm in the Mission, as there's sooooo many flavors I still want to try!
author: Sara S.

description:
I admit it, I came here for the hype of the chimney cone! Available only on Saturdays at 2pm, there was already a line about 10 people deep when I got there right at 2pm. I tried a couple of flavors, but tbh, I felt a little too rushed since they were trying to get people in and out ASAP. There are a variety of dairy and non-dairy flavors, ranging from your basic strawberry and cookies and cream, to hojicha, Japanese milk coffee, and mango sticky rice. All were pretty delicious, but if you want them in a chimney cone, you'll have to pick just one scoop.

For $8, I would not get the chimney cone again - the concept is cool, and the pic is totally instagrammable, but the warm freshly baked cone gets soggy pretty quickly, and your scoop of ice cream immediately starts sliding down into the cone and creating a soggy, soupy mess at the bottom of the paper sleeve. Granted, this is less of an issue in normally cold SF weather, so just something to take note of! I'd rather get a delicious pastry somewhere else and a scoop of ice cream in a regular cone. This all works out in the end bc that means I don't have to deal with the line for the chimney cone and can come whenever I want!
author: Lily C.

description: The lines are deceptively long, but it moves very fast.  Got to the front in 10 minutes and you can try many samples before buying.  I tried the Ube, Black sesame, and hochi cha flavor.  Hands down the best ube ice-cream I've ever tasted in SF.  It has the lightly sweet root flavor with just right texture of ube. It's hard to describe the taste, but it's almost a cross between a taro and a sweet potato. If it's available, GET IT and you will not regret it.  The black sesame is also great.  It has the nuttiness and the pungent flavor that just hits you as uniquely black sesame.  The flavors were on point and I didn't feel that it was too sweet.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I had never heard of Garden Creamery until their brick and mortar opened, but I've been dying to go ever since they popped up on my radar. 

We are huge fans of tea flavored ice cream so the hojicha (roast green tea) and genmaicha (brown rice tea) pictures on Yelp definitely caught our eyes; they are nearly impossible to find in ice cream form compared to matcha, which has become mainstream. Unfortunately for us they had neither when we stopped by tonight, but the guy behind the counter was so gracious and patiently let us sample basically half of their offerings. 

For $4.25, you get two flavors; my girlfriend had the banana lilikoi passion fruit and earl grey and said their earl grey is the best she's had, even beating out the one at Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous. I had the hardest time narrowing it down to two flavors but ultimately went with matcha gold (matcha with toffee) and the Thai tea (vegan). Hands down the most creative flavors in town, and yes, I've been to all the popular ice cream spots. I mean c'mon, Guabanero (guava-habanero)?!

They have a good amount of vegan options, and as someone who does not usually enjoy non-dairy milk in her ice cream, I have to say that the samples I tried were delicious. They rotate their flavors so if you don't see what you want on a given day, it'll probably be available if you come again.

Finding parking in the Mission is like winning the lottery, but we luckily found a spot right outside when we came on a Wednesday night around 7pm.
author: Olivia V.

description:
Garden Creamery has really made a name for themselves in the Instagram world with their beautiful CHIMNEY CONES - available Saturdays from 2-4 PM. 

Their ice cream is D E L I C I O U S and very creamy! I got the EARLY GREY & MANGO STICKY RICE. Both flavors were very light and the perfect amount of sweetness. I'd highly recommend trying both! 

I went around 3:15 PM on Saturday and I only waited for approximately 5-10 minutes, which I thought was pretty reasonable. The employees were also really friendly! 

And as for the CHIMNEY CONE, on its own I think it's delicious and made perfectly with a doughy soft inside. But I think the sweetness of the ice cream did mask how good the chimney cone really was. And *NOTE* you do only get one scoop on the chimney cone since there's a very good chance that it will topple over with 2+ scoops... so the pictures you see with 2 scoops are all creations of determined individuals who stacked the scoops themselves. 

Overall, I would definitely come back to try more of their ice cream flavors, but I think I'd pass on getting the chimney cone + 1 ice cream scoop for $8. It's definitely worth trying, but I'm a bigger fan of their ice cream alone!
author: Alison Y.

description:
How and why have I not discovered this SF gem until now??! Move over Bi-Rite because this place is amazing!! 

We got lucky on Saturday around 1pm and there were only about 5 people in front of us. Usually there is a line wrapped around the side of the building. We marveled at the abundant amount of flavors they had! So many exotic ones too....Mango with Li Hing Mui, Ube Pandan, Black Sesame, Lychee Black Tea....just to name a few! I think there was well over 20+ flavors to chose from. The servers let you sample as many flavors as you want and they were completely patient as we tried to decide. You can choose to have your scoops in a cup, waffle cone (which is light and delicious) or in a churro type cone (which I believe is only available during a certain time or day). 

I ended up with 2 generous scoops of the Black Sesame and the Lychee Black Tea in a waffle cone. Each bite was amazing and the flavors were exquisite. I made the right choice and I can't wait to return and try more flavors soon! 

Head here now!!!
author: La C.

description:
Gee, even I've heard of the Crunch Daddy which comes from the dessert truck run by Erin Lang and her boyfriend Donny. It consists of peanut butter or chocolate mousse-like ice cream squeezed between Rice Krispy treats, all of it dipped in chocolate. Praised by Eater SF as one of the top ice cream sandwiches around, the Crunch Daddy was on my mental wish list to try sometime. Lo and behold, Jamie W. and i just happened to be strolling to Dolores Park when we came upon their new corner spot at 20th and Lexington where she was personally scooping out her extensive selection of ice cream (photo: http://bit.ly/2jtTyPH).

Erin generously asked me if I wanted to sample any of the ice cream willing to oblige my every whim. Little did she know that I can't stand the skinny, indifferent women who insist on excessive sampling and try the patience of the customers behind them. Nope, I let her know I'd like to try the $4.25 Single in a cup which allowed me a small scoop of the Kona Coffee and a small scoop of the Haupia Macadamia Nut with Coconut Pudding (photo: http://bit.ly/2ki2JXC). The consistency was just right, creamy yet milky at the same time with the flavors not overly pronounced. With semifreddo pops and vegan sorbet also offered on the menu, a return visit is inevitable. Who am I kidding? I'll be a regular.

ICE CREAM - 4 stars....like the consistency and the flavors are more subtle than expected
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...cute corner spot on a residential block
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...Erin was beyond nice and grateful for the business
TOTAL - 4 stars...another reason to scream for ice cream
author: Ed U.

description:
I made a stop here due to the raving reviews for this place, which is probably due to their loyal fans from when this place was just a truck. Anyways, I tried a couple flavors before deciding on the Single Scoop ($4.25) with Hojicha and Strawberry Lychee. The hojicha (toasted green tea) was a very unique flavor where you can taste the blend of toasted and green tea --plus in my book! The strawberry lychee lacked some flavor on the lychee side, but still good and refreshing nonetheless.

This corner ice cream shop is a good alternative to the nearby Bi-Rite Creamery. The unique twist on the modern flavors is always a good factor for ice cream flavors. Also, noticed how the employee saw the table next to us cutting a cake and they brought out utensils and plates for them --how sweet!
author: Cindy Z.

description:
I absolutely loved the flavors I tried, Matcha Gold and Japanese Milk Coffee. I usually don't ever finish my ice cream leaving a couple bites behind. But not this time! I finished everything including my waffle cone which is also so addicting that I wanted more. 

I would definitely recommend and advice that you come off hours. If you come around 2-3, you will see a swarm of people heading over there for some dessert after lunch.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I love ice cream and have eaten at Smitten, Bi-Rite, Salt & Straw so I've eaten my fair share of ice cream in the city and around the world. I was excited to see this open up and it's now one of my new favorite ice cream places in the city. This is probably tied with Salt & Straw with favorite ice cream places in the city - this one having more unique, Asian-inspired flavors than Salt & Straw.

They have a chimney cone that is only served on Saturdays, and I need to come back to try it. But the lines are much shorter on a weekday night, and the waffle cone is fresh and also delicious (+$1).

They have flavors like matcha green tea, genmaicha, ube, black sesame, hazelnut crunch, mint chip, and other unique flavors. They also have vegan sorbet in flavors like thai tea, coconut. They have maybe 8 vegan flavors and maybe 16-20 regular dairy ice cream flavors. I got the genmaicha and the black sesame ice cream and I loved both of them. They were really unique, not super sweet, the texture was creamy, and it was just perfect. It's all hand-crafted, reasonably priced for the quality, and I'm almost glad I don't live closer or I would be here every week. I think they change out the flavors here and there, and they have a list of them online on their website. You can't go wrong though - the selection is wide enough that you'll find something you'll love and they also keep most of the staples around.

5 resounding stars - I can't wait to come back here for more. They take credit card which is always nice. The place is pretty small, so you'll have to eat your ice cream outside - don't expect ample seating for a big group inside. I like this better than Smitten and Bi-Rite (I know some people won't agree with me, but I think they have a better selection of flavors and the line is not as stupidly long on weekday nights)
author: Christina L.

description:
With flavors like ube pandan coconut (that's all in one) and mango sticky rice, how can you possibly go wrong??

I limited myself to trying two flavors here, but I can't wait to go back to try more! There are a handful of asian flavors (genmaicha, hojicha) and then some fun fusion ones (I usually am not a fan of fusion at all, but matcha gold = matcha + toffee sounds pretty cool)! The shop is pretty small, but the ice cream display case is nice and bright, the line moves quickly, and best of all, they take card! I'm also a fan of places that allow TWO flavors for a small/single serving. I'd definitely come back, and this place has quickly moved close to the top of my list of ice-cream spots in this city!
author: Christine L.

description: They have so many options for tea flavors! Finally settled down with 2: matcha with toffee, and genmaicha (matcha with roast rice). They're very creamy and smooth. I love them!
author: Zhihui H.

description:
Amazing!... and I haven't even tried the Churro cone yet. I already forewarn the future hubby that this place is awesome and my ice cream addiction is at it's peak! 

I love that there are no lines although I feel like it's coming. There isn't much in the Mission this good that stays hidden for long. Soon the hipsters at Dolores Park who won't want to wait hours for Bi-Rite will trek the additional blocks to Garden Creamery - ice cream truck turned brick and mortar.

Anyways, on to the goods. The coconut pandan flavor is amazing!! The black sesame isn't bad but can't trump the coco pandan. That one is FTW for me and will have me going back and back... One scoop of each. 2 scoops in a waffle cone: $5. Not bad!

The churro cone is only available Sat 2-4. Must go and try. It was a nice day and so it would have been nice to sit outside and enjoy my snack. Garden Creamery may want to set up some tables or seats for people before SF's Indian summer. Anyways, all in all, 5 stars!
author: Cicely T.

description:
Get yourself here, for reals.

Hojicha, Thai tea, mango sticky rice, ube, black sesame, Japanese milk tea.. yeah that's right. Those are ice cream flavors. Uh huh. Mmhm.

I have all positive things to say about ice cream here. The consistency is a great balance between icy and creamy, without the ice cream turning into a pool of liquid once it hits ambient temperatures. The flavors are thoroughly infused and stay true to their name. I love all things coffee and tea, so this was incredibly fun to eat. The biggest win is that nothing was too sweet, which I find as the limiting factor to most ice creams.

The wait time is variable depending on the time of day, but the line seems to move fairly quickly. I say come.
author: Cici T.

description:
My favorite ice cream spot in SF! I love all the tropical & Asian inspired flavors (always reminds my of Hawaii)! Typically, I never go for non-dairy stuff but here they are all good! I've honestly never had a flavor that I didn't like. 

Most recent flavors I tried - pumpkin mac nut, chocolate haupia, halo-halo and guava li himg mui 
Also love the haupia mac nut, ube and matcha variati
author: Laurie E.

description:
I love your ice cream, but please start serving fairly sized scoops again. Your prices are awfully high for the small amount served. It's frustrating to walk away with so little after paying so much. 

PS I live next to Mitchells and it's a very different situation with their servings
author: Yezin T.

description:
All the flavors looked amazing! but... #firstworldproblems, having too many ice cream flavors to choose from! 

Came here at about 1:55pm sharp on a sunny Saturday afternoon to get my hands on the Chimney Cone. Tried the strawberry guabanero (amazing!) and also tried the hojicha. They must've had about a handful of different type of green tea flavors alone. How's a girl to choose?

Decided to do a scoop of the black sesame on Chimney Cone. Glad I got my hands on one, glad I got my Instagram/snapchat/fb photo. Did leave a little sad knowing there's so many other flavors I haven't tried! The cone just tastes like white bread to me. Taste/texture wise, I would prefer a cone.
author: Tina S.

description: Really great dairy and Non diary choices. Tried the Thai tea (similar to Humphrey slocombe verison), the mango sticky rice but went with the Hawaiian macadamia coconut in a chimney cone. So good with chucks of coconut. The chimney cone had a tangy tasted within it. Overall very good. Would def come back.
author: Linda H.

description:
Wow.

My friend Judy L. brought me here promising something amazing and Garden Creamery more than delivered. Pricey, yes ($4.50 for a single, including tax), but the product is worth it! Best black sesame I've ever tasted; dense, nutty, creamy--delicious!!

And the server was a super nice, sweet teenager who let me try a bunch of flavors and was incredibly helpful in picking just the right flavor selections).

Highly, highly recommended!!
author: Cassidy P.

description:
Tried out the new ice cream shop in the Mission because of the Chimney Cone everyone on Instagram is getting. For now they only make them Saturdays from 2-4pm!!  I hope in the future it's everyday!

They have lots of dairy and non-dairy ice cream, you can ask for samples before making a selection.  I picked Black Sesame dairy, they also have a non-dairy version I didn't try.  With the Chimney Cone you can pick 1 flavor for $8.

I had to wait a few minutes because the chimney cone wasn't ready, then since it's still warm they put the ice cream in a cup and the cone on a sleeve.

It's really good.  Crunchy outside and soft and bread-like inside. It's a Hungarian thing called Kurtos Kalacs.

Well now you got to wait a week like I did, but it's worth it!

One unisex bathroom and they have a cute ice cream mirror inside there.  Credit cards are allowed.

20th St @ Lexington in the Mission.
author: Ann L.

description:
I stopped in this afternoon while in the area and overcome by a sudden craving for ice cream. There are lots of unique flavors to choose from. Everything I tasted was delicious and bursting with flavor. It's clear that they take care to use high quality, natural ingredients. They have a good mix of traditional and "off the beaten path" flavor options. 

I ultimately chose the Black Sesame flavor, which was creamy, nutty and tasted like sesame candy. It wasn't overpoweringly sweet and I really enjoyed how fresh the flavors were.

Prices weren't bad for the quality and portion size ($4.50 for a GIANT single cone). I also like that you can get 2 flavors in the single size. The line wasn't too long and moved quickly, and servers were efficient and helpful. It's a small space, but there are a few tables inside and it was easy to grab seating.
author: Christine G.

description:
For some reason, I didn't actually think that the Chimney cone would only be available on Saturdays 2-4pm. And so I was there on a Sunday at 6pm and I was disappointed to find out that there was no special cone. But since I already trekked all the way out to the Mission, why not have some ice cream anyway.

Like most ice cream shops, a few employees wait for customers behind the freezer with tubs of ice cream. The other thing is that these employees are some of the most inefficient workers I've ever seen. They did not manage the line well and caused the line to artificially balloon. 

After it was finally my turn and I tried a few flavor, we decided to get the Double Cone (up to 3 flavors) and grabbed an extra bowl for easy sharing. We got the Matcha Gold (matcha ice cream with toffee), Ube Pandan Coconut and Black Sesame. I liked that many of the flavors had a strong Asian influence (as with all 3 of the aforementioned choices) and the flavors were very bold and without being too sugary. I liked the Matcha Gold the best. But I guess I'll have to come back on a Saturday to experience the magic of the chimney cone.
author: Yi Z.

description: Had dinner at Naked Kitchen, which people should definitely check out if you have not! And even though we were full, I've been wanting to try the ice cream here for so long. After trying some flavors, everyone in our group decided to get some even though they were sure they didn't when we decided to head over - the flavors were great! The portion sizes are large too, you can get 2 flavors in a single, and it feels like a double! They did a full scoop of each flavor. The only thing I didn't love about this place was just the milkiness of the ice cream. I like my ice cream to be a little lighter and not have such a strong dairy taste. But it was still great and would love to be back to try the chimney cone one Saturday! They have a lot of Asian inspired flavors, as the owner is apparently Hawaiian!
author: Annie S.

description:
I love garden creamery. The icecream place is very clean, customer serrvice is friendly and they have so many flavors to choose from.

They have vegan options as well and will even ask if you're vegan for certain options just so that you won't eat a certain ingredient. 

I usually get ube and another flavor. I love mango and chocolate forsure! 

They get packed pretty quick so be aware of longish lines. 

Saturday they have cinnamon cones, long line for that and it's pretty delicate, be ware.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Best ice cream in San Francisco, a regular place for us. They have unqiue flavors with Hawaiian/Asian influence like ube pandan and roasted green tea (hojicha), and many other rotating ones. They also have really good non-dairy/vegan flavors like Thai tea, earl grey, and mango sticky rice.
author: Kevin B.

description: $4.50 for a single and it looks like the scoops are getting smaller since the last time I visited. Either that or my eyes and stomach are getting bigger. My friends and I joked that if we wanted to buy a hand-packed quart that it might cost more than $50. Lol. This place should have all the flavors posted on a sign or the window so the lines move faster. Solid ice cream but a tad on the pricey side.
author: W A.

description:
Yummy ice cream is always five stars :)

Garden Creamery offers a lot of well-executed flavors, including matcha toffee (never seen that combo- highly recommend), black sesame (the sesame tastes very toasty!), and a great non-dairy coconut. Reasonably priced. A 'single' cup with two flavors is $4.60.
author: Ricky D.

description: Came here after dinner around 8:30pm on a Saturday and there was a short line. It's definitely not easy to find parking here either so carpool, take public transportation or rideshare. There was a short line out the door when I arrived with sister and cousin so it was cold standing outside waiting for the moment we could be warmer inside. They provide samples and flavors change often. We got to sample a few before landing on our single scoops that allow 2 flavors max for $4.50 and $4.75 for single scoop (max 2 scoops) for sherbet. Mango sticky rice was interesting but not exactly the flavor of the dish, matcha toffee was good but I landed on the hojicha (roasted green tea) and ube pandan on a sugar cone. It was delicious and I believe hojicha is a usual flavor at this shop. They have a few green tea variations, so if you're a fan, definitely try. The hojicha was a rich & strong green tea flavor that I enjoyed so I liked it. I also tasted my sister's single scoop that allowed 2 scoops - guava habanero and Japanese coffee. The guava habanero was a sherbet which was interesting when it had a kick of spice at the end of a bite in your throat. Doesn't linger too long but definitely interesting. The coffee was a lot sweeter than regular coffee since it's Japanese coffee. Really enjoyed my ube pandan and hojicha enough to want to return to try other flavors. The milk ice creams were super rich and the sherbets were refreshing. They have seats in there but only about 4-5 tables. Highly suggest but I hope they make pints one day to sell so I can take home :p
author: Amanda C.

description:
Went with friends on a Saturday evening, and Garden Creamery was bustling. That being said, service was friendly and moved at a pace to match the crowd. We were not made to feel bad about sampling a few different flavors each, and ended up being happy with our orders. 

For vegans and lactase deficient folk, the nondairy selection was strong. I ordered a small, with one scoop of coconut and one scoop of apricots and cream. It was a delightful combo, and the coconut flavoring was on par with Holy Gelato, which is my gold standard for coconut gelatos. 

It seemed like the creamery was family run, which made me happy to see. The interior is small, but clean and stylish, with maximized seating area. Prices were steep for ice cream, but reasonable in the context of San Francisco. I believe the small costed $4.75. 

Friends got a lot of the ice creams, and those were excellent as well, based on my nibbles of their scoops. Highly recommend this little family run joint. If I'm in the area, I'll definitely be back.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Overall Score: 4
Service/Ambience: 3
Food Rating: 5

I got Vegan Coconut and Vegan Ube Coconut. Both tasted the same but the colors were so nice to look at. 

The cashier asked if I knew I was getting "sorbet" likely referencing that my options were vegan but vegan ice cream with coconut milk is not a sorbet. Surprised someone in an ice cream shop would not know the difference and the question just confused me. 

The place is also hotter than it is outside which made just buying the ice cream uncomfortable - it wasn't event busy.

---

Edit: 
I will compromise to say that this may fall into a gray area. 

Merriam-Webster defines

*sorbet* is usually fruit-flavored ice served as a dessert or between courses as a palate refresher

*sherbet* is defined as an ice with milk, egg white or gelatin added

I would personally classify the item as sherbet if anything but can see why sorbet is used. Overall, might as well just ask if I knew it was dairy-free!
author: Eddie Y.

description:
This ice cream place is just a little walk from Mission Delores Park. I've been wanting to try this place for so long but didn't read the reviews to learn that they only serve the chimney cones on Saturdays. But anyways, the place is so cute and the employees were really nice and helpful. 
Since there wasn't any chimney cones, I opted for a regular cake cone with the cookies and cream and the Japanese milk coffee flavors. The cookies and cream was like any normal cookies and cream ice cream but the coffee flavored ice cream was so good! Wish I ordered two scoops of that. 
Definitely will come back to try more flavors and the chimney cone!
author: Erin G.

description:
Last week I spent far too much time fantasizing about Garden Creamery's flavors: Genmaicha, butter mochi toasted sesame, coconut pandan. It seemed like time wasted since I had no plans to be anywhere in the vicinity of this Hawaiian inspired ice cream shop. 

Then yesterday, as my friend Paul and I made our way to dinner at Yuzuki I asked him to look up how far the restaurant was from Garden Creamery and much to my delight the answer was mere blocks! After finishing up our mushroom rice we headed for a much anticipated dessert. We arrived to find just a couple folks in front of us and a plethora of tasty treats before us. Despite my menu stalking, what we encountered in store was even better! Paul was especially pleased to find ube, a tropical taste he'd grown up with in the Philippines.

We both opted for single scoops (which come with your choice of two flavors). He had the ube macapuno and banana lilikoi and I had the haupia macadamia nut and the banana lilikoi. Our cones left us positively giddy. 

Garden Creamery, you live up to the hype! I'd wait in line at least fifteen minutes for the pleasure of your ice cream.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Mango sticky rice ice cream!!!! It tastes like mango and sticky rice... not sure how they do it. I wish they would sell gallons... errr pints* to go because I could eat an entire gallon to myself. 

Centrally located in the mission near Valencia so you can always convince your dinnermates to skip dessert at the restaurant to come here instead!!
author: Linda H.

description:
Y U M.

I came on a 3PM on a Saturday, and waited nearly ~30 minutes in line to get the ice cream here but it was so worth it. I got the Matcha Gold, the Ube Pandan, the and Boba Balls - each flavor warrants a review on its own with how delicious they were. I also tried a bunch of other flavors (sorry, I was that person today) and thought that each one was delicious. You really can't go wrong with this place!
author: Jessie Y.

description:
There seems to be no shortage of small, craft ice cream shops in San Francisco, but Garden Creamery brings a fresh selection and is a welcome addition to the neighborhood.

If you're a fan of unconventional flavors, tea flavored ice creams, or just Asian influenced ice cream, you'll love this place. There must be at least 10 tea based flavors, from jasmine green tea, to roasted green tea, to oolong, roasted oolong, etc. Black sesame, taro, and mango sticky rice are just a few of their other unique flavors. You're welcome to try as many flavors as you'd like.

This place can get busy on the weekends. I've yet to try their chimney cone, but will definitely be back during the time frame on a Saturday.
author: Tim X.

description: Worth the long wait! So many interesting flavors to choose from! I ordered the black sesame and genmaicha. Def never had genmaicha ice cream before but both were super good! I must come back on a Saturday afternoon to try their chimney cones.
author: Annie H.

description:
WORTH. THE. HYPE.

Too many times have I been disappointed by people telling me, "Oh, my gosh. This place is amazing." and end up being disappointed when I try it myself. Not this time. 

The thing I love about this place is that a lot of the flavors are Asian-influenced. Even though more places are trying out Asian flavors these days, they're not always good. All the flavors I sampled at this place were great. Although it was hard to choose, I ended up getting a single cone of Genmaicha and Cookie butter. They tasted exactly as described and weren't overly sweet. I can't describe exactly how good they were, so you're just going to have to go there and try them yourself.
author: Lucinda H.

description:
It's good not great. There's sooo much ice cream competition in this city, they need to up there game big-time.

I'd go back if I were in the neighborhood, otherwise it's not worth the effort.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Decided to give this place a try, and I do not regret it all. 

I came here on a Sunday afternoon around 2pm, and there wasn't much of a line. There were like 4-5 people in front of us. If you're driving, you'll need to find street parking. 

They have a selection of unique ice cream flavors, such as black sesame, matcha gold, banana salted caramel, mango, earl grey, and more! 

I got a single waffle cone with a scoop of matcha gold and a scoop of Tahitian vanilla bean. Both flavors were so freakin' good. I will definitely come back for more ice cream!

Also, this is a good place if you want an instaworthy foodie pic :)
author: Linda C.

description: A friend recommended this place to me, because she lives so near. It's definitely an asian oriented ice-cream place, which I definitely love. Their mango sticky rice is amazing AND dairy free. They somehow got that slight roasted sesame flavor at the end exactly right. So amazing. My favorite flavor here is probably the roasted matcha- the hojicha. SO GOOD. The japanese milk tea is good too. There are also Filipino cuisine inspired flavors as well. We typically get the single scoop, which comes with two flavors, technically two scoops. They give pretty huge scoops, at least bigger than Smitten, so the price point feels worth it. We usually have 2 people finish one cup/single scoop because this ice cream is fulfilling. There's usually a long line so be prepared to wait a bit.
author: Michelle R.

description: I got the black sesame and the hojicha. If I lived anywhere closer to this place my bowels will not be happy because I would eat it all the time, even though I'm lactose. But it's worth it. The ice cream variety is surprisingly large and the flavors are very well balanced.
author: Hagop B.

description:
Ice cream review.

Flavor variety - 4/5
Flavor uniqueness - 5/5
Taste - 5/5
Texture - 5/5 - Creamiest ice cream in SF.
Chimney cone - 5/5 - Get this. Limited availability. 

Especially good flavors: 
Coconut
Butter mochi + Toasted sesame
Matcha + Toasted rice
Haupia Mac nut
Japanese milk coffee 

Other flavors tried:
Banana Lilikoi passion
Roasted butter pistachio

Overall, "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description: Delicious Asian-inspired flavors, and perhaps the only ice cream place in SF that serves hojicha-flavored ice cream. Also a huge fan of the black sesame. Surprisingly wasn't a huge fan of the mango sticky rice flavor, not did I particularly like the Chimney cone they have on Saturday afternoons. Too bad they don't have the capacity to sell pints (yet?). Biggest complaint is that lately they have become noticeably stingy with their scoops.
author: Denise H.

description: I've always wanted to come here on a Saturday to get the chimney cone (churro cone) but never got the chance to. Instead, I came here on a late Thursday afternoon to try it out anyway. Garden Creamery has a wide selection of interesting flavors! It can range from coconut, Thai tea, green tea, Japanese milk coffee to ube. I ended up getting matcha ice cream with toffee bits and earl grey. Who knew matcha and toffee would be a nice combination together! I'm definitely coming back here to try other flavors. This might be my new favorite spot to get ice cream.
author: Sarah F.

description:
This place is good, but I have to say the Yelp reviews and half a mile long line out the door got me a bit more hyped than I felt when I actually tried it for myself. I went late at night, so maybe that's my fault, but they looked like they were getting ready to close and were sold out of most of the ice cream bars that were listed on their website.

The service was great and the ice cream was definitely delicious, but it didn't blow past any other ice cream options I had tried in the recent months. Some interesting flavors, but I'm usually pretty conservative when it comes to ice cream. Also, it's nearly impossible to find a chance at getting those churro cones, since they are sold in such limited quantity in a small window of time. I'm not sure if I have the personal motivation to get there early just to experience it, but I do love a good churro filled with ice cream.
author: Veronica B.

description:
Deep flavor!  That is what you'll find in every single selection here.  I'm not one that usually eats ube ice cream, but man, their ube pandan is everything!  That with some mango sticky rice and Mmmmmm, I am set.  This place has such a good variety that I'm drawn to it any time I think of ice cream now.  Favorites besides the ube pandan and mango sticky rice include strawberry lychee, black sesame, matcha gold, chocolate (dairy and non-dairy) and butter mochi sesame.  

Haven't tried the chimney cone, but probably don't need to as the ice cream can really hold it's own without bells and whistles.  

Lick it!
author: Maria S.

description: Planned my whole day around coming to this creamery for the chimney churro cones between 2-4 on Saturday's! I was first in line for them and they did not disappoint!  We ordered two chimney churro cones with ube Icecream and a banana flavored Icecream. Both were creamy, delicious and paired well with the warm pull apart churro cone. It was a match made in heaven and worth the wait. If you are in San Francisco you need need need to go here for quality Icecream and especially those churro cones! I can't wait to travel back to San Francisco and have a double scoop next time!
author: Celeste M.

description: I love their variety of ice cream flavors and their atmosphere is so inviting and relaxing. I came here with two friends and we enjoyed our ice cream in their lovely booths. I recommend their black sesame ice cream with their Japanese milk coffee, so delicious and unexpected !! If you love trying new things and have an affinity for Asian flavors then definitely come and try something new to fill your sweet tooth cravings.
author: Diana C.

description:
The best ice cream in San Francisco. Yes, I will fight you.

I've been here multiple times and loved every single flavor I've gotten. The flavors, texture, creaminess and oh my god the chimney cones are all excellent. I wish they sold their ice cream in pints so I could eat my feelings whenever I wanted.

Pro-tip: Mix the Ube ice cream with Vanilla bean and brownie ice cream for a unique combination of flavors and textures and mouth heaven
author: Max N.

description:
This little spot it Ok. With the abundance of Ice Cream Shops in the area, it'll be a while before I come back.
 
The Ice Cream here is great but it's not the best. Any other city this would be a gem but this is San Francisco so you've got to try just a little harder.  

The Banana Salt Carmel is great. I'd come back just for that.

Friendly and fast! I wish them the best luck but there are at least a dozen other places I'd go before coming back.
author: Justin S.

description: You must come on Saturday around 2pm because of churro cone. I came earlier, so I wish I will visit again for churro cone next time. But it still worth coming for ice cream. Tsasty!
author: Jenny H.

description:
My favorite creamery in the bay area period.

If you are a green tea fan, you can't miss this place. They have 4 different types of green tea flavor ice cream, and also a killer black sesame ice cream. And what's even better? Their CHIMNEY CONE! Yes it's a bit pricey, but I guarantee that you will go back for more.The only thing I was not a fan was their waffle cone - I had better.

You can have up to 5 flavors for tasting, and the chimney cone is only available on saturday (2-4pm I believe...). There will be a line, but it's totally worth it!
author: Louisa L.

description: As good as everybody says it is! Had the pandan coconut and fresh mint chip today and it was excellent. Super creamy and full flavored featuring farmers market fruits and herbs. Yum!
author: Jammy M.

description:
This place deserves so much more hype than it gets.

Came here on a Sunday. To get here from the Castro, I walked by Bi Rite whose line was CRAZY. I haven't tried Bi Rite so I guess I shouldn't comment. But I will. Because when I got to Garden Creamery the line was so much shorter. And that shouldn't be the case!!

Was there still a line? Yes. But the line was only about 10 people deep, shorter than even the Boba Guys I walked by as well (which is a chain, so I don't care how good that might be, it doesn't deserve a longer line).

The line moves fairly quickly, because people are dumb and don't try all the flavors. It boggles my mind... With a wide range of unique flavors that have Asian inspiration, why wouldn't you try them all?! I did, and the worker was very nice about it. +1

I ultimately ended up getting a waffle cone with the black sesame, macadamia nut, and the thai tea. Oh my god, they were all so delicious. The thai tea tasted just like thai tea, but creamier. I didn't know thai tea could get creamier, but somehow they managed. The black sesame was top notch and the macadamia nut had some lovely coconut flavoring going on.

For a total of around 6 or 7 bucks, Garden Creamery delivers. If you want some unique flavors, that once you taste you feel should be mainstream, come here. If you're boring, stay far, far away.
author: Angela C.

description:
Ah.  Food trends, hypes, and fads; gotta love them and hate them at the same time!  I'm not sure if there's ever be an "odd" one that I totally love.  But if something looks good, I'll make an attempt to try it!  After seeing Garden Creamery's chimney cones trending on Instagram almost non stop.  I knew I had to try this carby treat topped with one of their signature ice cream flavors.  

We finished up brunch nearby at Hog & Rocks last Saturday about 45 minutes until GC serves these hot treats which is only on Saturdays from 2-4 (or until they run out).  They're fresh baked onsite.  We got there early to scope it out (a little before 1:30PM) and chatted with a really nice couple there.  They said they didn't know that it was served starting at 2, so they were waiting around, and we all decided to wait around and sample flavors.  Until more couples came in waiting for the cones.
